SubTopics: Describe and graph the amounts and percentages of water and fresh water in various reservoirs to provide evidence about the distribution of water on Earth.
Content: Students are investigating the different types of freshwater on Earth. The students study the diagram below.
problems/MOG5S/media/1a.jpg
Using data from the diagram, make a bar graph that shows the percentages of the types of freshwater on Earth.

SubTopics: Make observations during different seasons to relate the amount of daylight to the time of year.
Content: A student in Missouri records the average number of daylight hours during four months of the year. The results are shown in the data table below.
problems/MOG5S/media/2a.jpg
Which conclusion is BEST supported by the data provided?

A.Choice: The sun is larger and brighter in May and August than it is in February and November.

B.Choice: Earth rotates slower on its axis in May and August than it does in February and November.

C.Choice: Earth is closer to the sun’s orbit around the planets in May and August than it is in February and November.

D.Choice: The Northern Hemisphere receives more direct sunlight in May and August than it does in February and November.

SubTopics: Represent data in graphical displays to reveal patterns of daily changes in length and direction of shadows, day and night, and the seasonal appearance of some stars in the night sky.
Content: A student takes a picture of the shadow of a house at four different times during one day. The pictures are shown below, but they are not in order according to the time they were taken.
Correctly order  the pictures according to the time of day when each picture was taken. Write the number of each picture in one of the boxes to show this order.

SubTopics: Use evidence to construct an explanation for how the variations in characteristics among individuals of the same species may provide advantages in surviving and finding mates.
Content: A zoo in Missouri wants to build a new enclosure for yellow mud turtles, which are native to parts of the state.
problems/MOG5S/media/4a.jpg
The table below shows some features of yellow mud turtles in the wild and some characteristics of the new zoo enclosure.
problems/MOG5S/media/4b.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS THREE PARTS.
Describe how the turtles will be positively affected by the new zoo enclosure.
Describe how the turtles will be negatively affected by the new zoo enclosure.
Describe one way in which the zoo enclosure could be changed to help the turtles.

SubTopics: Support an argument that relative distances from Earth affects the apparent brightness of the sun compared to other stars.
Content: A student made the following model of the water cycle.
problems/MOG5S/media/5a.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS THREE PARTS.
The student adds a bag of ice on top of the plastic wrap. Describe how this change will affect the water vapor rising from the cup.
Describe how the model can be changed to increase the rate of water moving through the water cycle.
Identify the TWO Earth systems that are represented by the cup of water and the bag of ice in the model.
Bag of Ice: :FR-1:
Cup of Water: :FR-2:

SubTopics: Make observations during different seasons to relate the amount of daylight to the time of year.
Content: A student is investigating how the amount of daylight changes with the time of year in Missouri. The data table shown is used by the student in the investigation.
problems/MOG5S/media/6a.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS THREE PARTS.
The student decides to collect data on the twenty-first day of each month. Explain why collecting data on the same day of each month is a good idea.
The student collects data for one year and notices a pattern. Describe this pattern.
Describe the relationship between the pattern in the amount of daylight during a year and the different seasons on Earth.

SubTopics: Identify evidence from patterns in rock formations and fossils in rock layers to support an explanation for changes in a landscape over time.
Content: A scientist observes some layers of sedimentary rock on a cliff. The layers of sedimentary rock contain fossils. The scientist makes a drawing of the observations. The scientist’s drawing is shown.
problems/MOG5S/media/7a.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Identify the oldest layer of rock on the cliff and use evidence from the drawing to explain your answer.

A.Choice: layer W

B.Choice: layer X

C.Choice: layer Y

D.Choice: layer Z

Content: Explain how the environment in the area observed by the scientist changed over time. Be sure to include TWO different examples, with evidence, from the drawing.

SubTopics: Construct an argument that plants and animals have internal and external structures that function to support survival, growth, behavior, and plant reproduction.
Content: A student wants to investigate the role of stolons in buffalo grass reproduction. The student performs the following steps in an investigation.

:ibox:Buffalo Grass Investigation Steps

• Plant buffalo grass in two plots of land.
• Care for buffalo grass until it spreads over a large area in both plots.
• Separate the buffalo grass by cutting the stolons between plants.
Which result would provide the BEST evidence that stolons help the plant reproduce?

A.Choice: The number of plants decreased.

B.Choice: The soil around the plants becomes dry.

C.Choice: The separated plants continue to grow.

D.Choice: The separated plants’ leaves change color.

SubTopics: Construct an argument that plants and animals have internal and external structures that function to support survival, growth, behavior, and plant reproduction.
Content: The drawings show a red buckeye flower and a hummingbird.
problems/MOG5S/media/9a.jpg
problems/MOG5S/media/9b.jpg
A student observes a hummingbird using its long beak to get nectar from a red buckeye flower.
Choose the correct phrases to complete the statement about the student’s observation.
:DD-1: external structures that aid in survival. These structures also help the organism(s) :DD-2: .

1:C.Choice: Both the red buckeye and the hummingbird have

SubTopics: Construct an argument that plants and animals have internal and external structures that function to support survival, growth, behavior, and plant reproduction.
Content: Students would expect to see more frogs near the school with an increase in native plants. Frogs have sticky tongues that they use to catch insects.
Select the TWO statements that describe how a frog’s tongue helps it survive.

A.Choice: A frog’s tongue can perform the function of any other structure in a frog.

B.Choice: A frog’s tongue has a specific function in how a frog grows and develops.

C.Choice: A frog’s tongue works separately from other structures in the frog to help it survive.

D.Choice: A frog’s tongue is the only structure that helps to break food down into smaller parts.

E.Choice: A frog’s tongue is one of many structures that work together to support growth and reproduction.

SubTopics: Use evidence to construct an explanation for how the variations in characteristics among individuals of the same species may provide advantages in surviving and finding mates.
Content: Butterflies are often observed in grassy areas with many flowering plants. They have a long, thin structure called a proboscis, which is used to collect nectar from flowers. Which statement BEST describes how butterflies would survive in a new area with some tall trees and very few flowering plants?

A.Choice: Butterflies would survive well in the new area because they rely on other butterflies for food.

B.Choice: Butterflies would survive well in the new area because trees provide shade for the butterflies.

C.Choice: Butterflies would not survive well in the new area because they eat food produced by the flowering plants.

D.Choice: Butterflies would not survive well in the new area because the trees would block the sunlight they need to produce energy.

SubTopics: Use evidence to construct an explanation for how the variations in characteristics among individuals of the same species may provide advantages in surviving and finding mates.
Content: Students at a school are considering mixing rough bluegrass into the school’s lawn of buffalo grass. Rough bluegrass is not native to Missouri. It grows best in wet and shady areas. It stays green throughout the winter but will turn brown without enough rainfall or if too many people walk on it. Like buffalo grass, rough bluegrass also reproduces through the use of stolons.
Explain whether the students should use rough bluegrass in the school lawn in addition to buffalo grass. Be sure to include at least TWO reasons supporting your explanation.

SubTopics: Develop a model to compare and contrast observations on the life cycle of different plants and animals.
Content: A student began to develop the simple life cycle model shown below.
problems/MOG5S/media/13a.jpg
Which changes should the student make to the model to best represent the life cycle of buffalo grass?

A.Choice:
1. Move step 2 before step 1.
2. Add the label “death” in step 4.

B.Choice:
1. Add the label “survival” in step 4.
2. Add a step for “pollination” after step 4.

C.Choice:
1. Remove step 2.
2. Add the label “growth” in the new step 3.

D.Choice:
1. Add the label “death” in step 4.
2. Add a step for “pollination” between steps 2 and 3.

SubTopics: Make observations and/or measurements of an object’s motion to provide evidence that a pattern can be used to predict future motion.
Content: The student wants to use the results from Investigation 1 to predict whether the paper clip will rise to stick to the magnet in a new investigation.
Based on the data provided, determine the lowest height at which the paper clip will be unable to rise and stick to the magnet.

A.Choice: 8 cm

B.Choice: 13 cm

C.Choice: 21 cm

D.Choice: 27 cm

SubTopics: Plan and conduct investigations to separate the components of a mixture/solution by their physical properties (i.e., sorting, filtration, magnets, screening).
Content: The student watched an online video of a falling paper clip. When the video was played in slow motion, the paper clip could be observed moving side to side as it fell to the ground.

The student stated that the force of gravity was responsible for both the paper clip’s downward motion and its side-to-side motion. Identify whether the student is correct or incorrect AND provide an explanation.

A.Choice: Correct

B.Choice: Incorrect

SubTopics: Plan and conduct investigations to determine the cause and effect relationship of electric or magnetic interactions between two objects not in contact with each other.
Content: Which conclusion about why the paper clip only moved during two of the trials is supported by the data from Investigation 1?

A.Choice: The paper clip moved because the magnet was touching the paper clip in two of the trials.

B.Choice: The paper clip moved because the force exerted by the magnet was close enough to the paper clip to move it.

C.Choice: The paper clip moved because the magnet was able to transfer energy to the paper clip during two of the trials.

D.Choice: The paper clip moved because the magnet was more powerful when it was closer to the paper clip.

SubTopics: Make observations and/or measurements of an object’s motion to provide evidence that a pattern can be used to predict future motion.
Content: Which statement accurately compares the observations made in both investigations?

A.Choice: The experiments showed that both gravity and magnetism act only on metals.

B.Choice: The experiments showed that both gravity and magnetism can attract an object.

C.Choice: The experiments showed that gravity attracts objects and magnetism repels objects.

D.Choice: The experiments showed that gravity and magnetism always act in opposite directions.

SubTopics: Make observations and/or measurements of an object’s motion to provide evidence that a pattern can be used to predict future motion.
Content: Choose words or phrases in each set of options to complete the statement based on data from Investigation 2.
If the paper clip had been dropped from a :DD-1: height, then the speed of the paper clip would have :DD-2: .

SubTopics: Make observations and/or measurements of an object’s motion to provide evidence that a pattern can be used to predict future motion.
Content: The student uses the data table from Investigation 2 to make predictions about the behavior of other falling objects dropped from different heights. Which prediction can the student make about the behavior of other falling objects based on these data?

A.Choice: The total distance fallen will increase at a faster rate over time.

B.Choice: The total distance fallen will decrease at a faster rate over time.

C.Choice: The total distance fallen will increase at a constant rate over time.

D.Choice: The total distance fallen will decrease at a constant rate over time.

SubTopics: Plan and conduct investigations to determine the cause and effect relationship of electric or magnetic interactions between two objects not in contact with each other.
Content: Based on the observations made in Investigation 1, which statement BEST describes the interaction between the horseshoe magnet and the paper clip?

A.Choice: The horseshoe magnet repels the paper clip when the paper clip is farther away.

B.Choice: The horseshoe magnet applies more attractive force on the paper clip from nearby than from farther away.

C.Choice: The paper clip applies more magnetic force on the horseshoe magnet when thehorseshoe magnet is farther away.

D.Choice: The paper clip and the horseshoe magnet repel each other at close distances and attract each other when farther apart.

SubTopics: Plan and conduct investigations to separate the components of a mixture/solution by their physical properties (i.e., sorting, filtration, magnets, screening).
Content: The student has developed three options to model Investigation 2.
problems/MOG5S/media/21a.jpg
problems/MOG5S/media/21b.jpg
problems/MOG5S/media/21c.jpg
ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Choose the model that BEST shows how gravity affected the paper clip as it fell.

A.Choice: Model X

B.Choice: Model Y

C.Choice: Model Z

Content: Choose the source of the gravitational force that was acting on the paper clip.

A.Choice: push from Earth’s atmosphere

B.Choice: pull from the center of Earth

C.Choice: pull from the surface of Earth

SubTopics: Support an argument that the gravitational force exerted by Earth on objects is directed toward the planet's center.
Content: Students are given a mixture of iron filings and sand.
problems/MOG5S/media/22a.jpg
Which method could the students use to separate the mixture into its individual components?

A.Choice: pour the mixture through a filter

B.Choice: cool the mixture in a refrigerator

C.Choice: stir the mixture with a bar magnet

D.Choice: place the mixture in a container of water

SubTopics: Use evidence to construct an explanation for how the variations in characteristics among individuals of the same species may provide advantages in surviving and finding mates.
Content: The drawing below shows a porcupine.
problems/MOG5S/media/23a.jpg
Select each of the characteristics that help a porcupine survive in its environment in the table below.

A.Choice: has sharp claws

B.Choice: has many predators

C.Choice: has long, strong teeth

D.Choice: has short legs and runs slowly

SubTopics: Construct scientific arguments to support claims that some characteristics of organisms are inherited from parents and some are influenced by the environment.
Content: The list below includes some characteristics of a puppy.

:ibox:Puppy Characteristics

• ears that face forward
• tip of nose is dark colored
• short coat (fur length
• scar on one of its front paws
A student states that all of the puppy’s characteristics in the list were inherited from its parents. Which statement BEST explains whether the student is correct or incorrect?

A.Choice: The student is correct because the length of the puppy’s fur was inherited.

B.Choice: The student is correct because everything on an animal’s body is inherited.

C.Choice: The student is incorrect because the scar on the puppy’s paw was not inherited.

D.Choice: The student is incorrect because the color of the puppy’s nose was not inherited.

SubTopics: Use evidence to construct an explanation for how the variations in characteristics among individuals of the same species may provide advantages in surviving and finding mates.
Content: The table below compares some fish and the water temperatures in which they live.
problems/MOG5S/media/25a.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Identify the fish that is able to live in the warmest habitat.

A.Choice: chum salmon

B.Choice: rainbow trout

C.Choice: spotted bass

D.Choice: yellow perch

Content: A student states that the chum salmon and the spotted bass can be found in the same river. Explain whether the data provided supports the student’s statement or not.

SubTopics: Develop a model to describe the movement of matter among plants, animals, decomposers, and the environment.
Content: A model of an energy pyramid is shown below.
problems/MOG5S/media/26a.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS THREE PARTS.
Describe a relationship between organisms in level W and organisms in level X in the model.
Identify TWO things that are passed from organisms in level Y to organisms in level X in the model.
Thing 1: :FR-1:
Thing 2: :FR-2:
Describe a type of organism that should be included in level Z in the model.

SubTopics: Use evidence to construct an explanation for how the variations in characteristics among individuals of the same species may provide advantages in surviving and finding mates.
Content: A group of snails lives in a dark forest. Some of the snails have white shells, and some of the snails have brown shells. The drawings below show how the shell color for the group of snails changed over three generations.
problems/MOG5S/media/27a.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS THREE PARTS.
Explain why having a brown shell in a dark forest is an advantage over having a white shell.
Explain why the number of snails with brown shells has increased over time.
Describe a possible change to the forest that could result in an increase in the number of snails with white shells.

SubTopics: Measure and graph quantities to provide evidence that regardless of the type of change that occurs when heating, cooling, or mixing substances, the total weight of matter is conserved.
Content: A student performs the following procedure:

:ibox:Procedure

1. Measure 25 grams of an unknown solid.
2. Measure 200 grams of water.
3. Pour the unknown solid and water into a beaker, which weighs 50 grams.
4. Stir the solution.
The student records the following observation:

:ibox:Observation

About half of the unknown solid dissolves and the other half settles to the bottom of the beaker.
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
The student calculated the combined weight of the unknown solid and the water to be 275 grams. Describe the mistake the student made in this calculation.
Describe how stirring the solution will affect the total amount of matter in this investigation.

SubTopics: Support an argument that the gravitational force exerted by Earth on objects is directed toward the planet's center.
Content: The student makes a mistake and mixes the white sugar in the hot water instead of mixing the baking soda in the hot water. Which investigation setup would BEST help the student separate the white sugar from the water?

A.Choice:
:box:1. Stir the liquid with a powerful magnet.
2. Allow the magnet and the particles stuck to it to dry off on a paper towel.
3. White sugar can then be scraped off the magnet.

B.Choice:
:box:1. Heat the liquid over a source of heat.
2. Allow the water to evaporate.
3. White sugar can be collected after all the water has evaporated.

C.Choice:
:box:1. Pour the liquid into a container and place a lid on it.
2. Allow the liquid in the container to sit overnight.
3. White sugar will float to the top of the water and can be scooped out.

D.Choice:
:box:1. Pour the liquid through a screen.
2. Allow the particles left on the screen to completely dry.
3. White sugar can then be collected from the screen.

SubTopics: Support an argument that the gravitational force exerted by Earth on objects is directed toward the planet's center.
Content: The student places some of the dry ingredients into a bowl and stirs the ingredients until they are mixed thoroughly.

:ibox:Dry Ingredients

• flour
• salt
• brown sugar
• chocolate chips
The student wants to use a screen to separate the mixture into its individual components. Which statement describes how the student’s plan will MOST LIKELY work?

A.Choice: The student’s plan will work. The screen is designed to separate solids from other solids.

B.Choice: The student’s plan will not work. The screen can only be used to separate liquids from solids.

C.Choice: The student’s plan will work. The screen will allow the smaller particles (flour, salt, and brown sugar) to pass through its openings.

D.Choice: The student’s plan will not work. The screen will only separate the larger particles (chocolate chips) from the other ingredients.

SubTopics: Conduct an investigation to determine whether the combining of two or more substances results in new substances.
Content: The student decides to perform a separate investigation to see how baking with white sugar compares to baking with brown sugar. The student performs the following two procedures.

:ibox:Procedure 1

• Measure 1/4 cup of white sugar.
• Measure 1/2 cup of butter.
• Combine the ingredients with a spoon and place the mixture in a pan.
• Bake the mixture in an oven for one hour.

:ibox:Procedure 2

• Measure 1/4 cup of brown sugar.
• Measure 1 cup of butter.
• Combine the ingredients with a spoon and place the mixture in a pan.
• Bake the mixture in an oven for 45 minutes.
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Choose TWO ways the student’s investigation could be changed to make it a fair test.

A.Choice: Use the same amount of butter in both procedures.

B.Choice: Combine the ingredients with a different tool.

C.Choice: Bake the mixtures for the same amount of time.

D.Choice: Use different ovens for both procedures.

Content: Choose one observation that would help the student decide whether a new substance was formed during the investigation.

A.Choice: The baked result has properties different from those of the original ingredients.

B.Choice: The oven is warmer after baking than it was before baking.

C.Choice: Both of the original ingredients can be seen in the baked result.

D.Choice: The color of the original ingredients did not change during baking.

SubTopics: Develop a model to describe that matter is made of particles too small to be seen.
Content: The student wants to develop a model to represent how the baking soda is affected in step 3 of the procedure. Which description of a model would BEST represent this process?

A.Choice: A balloon fills up with air. The balloon and the air remain large enough to be seen.

B.Choice: A balloon fills up with air. The balloon can be seen, but the air is too small to be seen.

C.Choice: Salt and pepper are mixed together. The salt and the pepper become too small to be seen.

D.Choice: Salt and pepper are mixed together. The pepper and the salt remain large enough to be seen.

SubTopics: Measure and graph quantities to provide evidence that regardless of the type of change that occurs when heating, cooling, or mixing substances, the total weight of matter is conserved.
Content: Before baking the cookies, the student measures the weight of the prepared cookie dough. Which graph BEST represents how the amount of matter inside the oven is affected by the cooking process?

A.Choice: problems/MOG5S/media/33a.jpg

B.Choice: problems/MOG5S/media/33b.jpg

C.Choice: problems/MOG5S/media/33c.jpg

D.Choice: problems/MOG5S/media/33d.jpg

SubTopics: Measure and graph quantities to provide evidence that regardless of the type of change that occurs when heating, cooling, or mixing substances, the total weight of matter is conserved.
Content: The student measures the combined weight of all the ingredients before the cookie dough is made. After the cookies are baked in the oven and allowed to cool, the student weighs the finished cookies. The weight of the cookies is less than that of their ingredients.
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Explain what happened to the matter that is not part of the finished cookies.
Identify one possible cause for the lighter weight of the cookies compared to that of the ingredients.

SubTopics: Make a claim about the merit of an existing design solution (e.g. levies, tornado shelters, sea walls, etc.) that reduces the impacts of a weather-related hazard.
Content: Choose the correct words or phrases to complete the following statement.
A student states that if the seawall had been built before 1900, there would have been :DD-1: damage and :DD-2: people would have been injured in 1900.

SubTopics: Make a claim about the merit of an existing design solution (e.g. levies, tornado shelters, sea walls, etc.) that reduces the impacts of a weather-related hazard.
Content: Which statement explains why the Galveston hurricane of 1900 caused so much damage?

A.Choice: Most buildings were hit by flying objects picked up by high winds.

B.Choice: The storm surge caused flooding that washed away many buildings.

C.Choice: Most buildings were destroyed by tornadoes resulting from the hurricane.

D.Choice: The thunderstorms were so strong that many buildings were struck by lightning.

SubTopics: Represent data in tables and graphical displays to describe typical weather conditions expected during a particular season.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Use the information in Table 1 to make a bar graph of the atmospheric pressure in Galveston for the evening of September 8, 1900.
Which statement describes a cause-and-effect relationship between atmospheric pressure and a characteristic of a hurricane?

A.Choice: As the atmospheric pressure increases, wave activity changes from calm to active.

B.Choice: As the atmospheric pressure decreases, the wind speed changes from low to high.

C.Choice: As the atmospheric pressure decreases, the skies change from cloudy to partly cloudy.

D.Choice: As the atmospheric pressure increases, the weather changes from a drizzle to heavy rain.

SubTopics: Represent data in tables and graphical displays to describe typical weather conditions expected during a particular season.
Content: Based on Table 2 and other information in the scenario, which chart includes the MOST LIKELY wind speed for the Galveston hurricane of 1900 and provides evidence to support that wind speed?

A.Choice: problems/MOG5S/media/38a.jpg

B.Choice: problems/MOG5S/media/38b.jpg

C.Choice: problems/MOG5S/media/38c.jpg

D.Choice: problems/MOG5S/media/38d.jpg

SubTopics: Generate and compare multiple solutions to reduce the impacts of natural Earth processes on humans.
Content: The Galveston seawall protects the island from hurricanes up to category 4. Which change to the current seawall is MOST LIKELY to protect Galveston from a category 5 hurricane?

A.Choice: The length of the current seawall would have to be shortened because category 5 hurricanes can produce heavy flooding.

B.Choice: The current seawall would have to be rebuilt to allow water to pass through it because category 5 hurricanes produce large waves.

C.Choice: The height of the current seawall would have to be increased because category 5 hurricanes have a storm surge of more than 18 feet.

D.Choice: The width of the current seawall would have to be increased because category 5 hurricanes have wind speeds of more than 155 mph.

SubTopics: Obtain and combine information about ways individual communities use science ideas to protect the Earth’s resources and environment.
Content: Building the seawall in Galveston has had both positive and negative effects.
Categorize the following effects as either postivie or negative.

A:protects the island from damage from w.Choice: 1:Positive Effect(s) of Building the Galveston Seawall

B:changed a natural ecosystem to a human.Choice: 2:Negative Effect(s) of Building the Galveston Seawall

C:provides a place for people to play.Choice: 1:Positive Effect(s) of Building the Galveston Seawall

SubTopics: Make a claim about the merit of an existing design solution (e.g. levies, tornado shelters, sea walls, etc.) that reduces the impacts of a weather-related hazard.
Content: A map of Galveston Island with possible locations for the seawall is shown below.
problems/MOG5S/media/41a.jpg
ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Choose the area where the people of Galveston MOST LIKELY built the seawall in 1904.

A.Choice: Area 1

B.Choice: Area 2

C.Choice: Area 3

Content: Choose the explanation that BEST supports this decision.

A.Choice: This location is designed to protect the city center from future events.

B.Choice: This location is designed to reduce winds moving from land toward the Gulf of Mexico.

C.Choice: This location is designed to limit the amount of water moving between the island and the mainland of Texas.

SubTopics: Generate and compare multiple solutions to reduce the impacts of natural Earth processes on humans.
Content: A seawall is designed to protect cities from the effects of a hurricane. A student developed two seawall models to possibly reduce the impacts of a hurricane on a nearby city.
problems/MOG5S/media/42a.jpg
problems/MOG5S/media/42b.jpg
Which pair of statements identifies the model that would be MOST effective at decreasing the impacts of a hurricane and explains why?

A.Choice: Model Y would be most effective. The seawall would stop wind from directly hitting the buildings in the city.

B.Choice: Model Y would be most effective. The seawall would reduce the amount of ocean water that could rise up and flood the city.

C.Choice: Model X would be most effective. The wind channels would allow water to flow through the seawall and decrease wave action.

D.Choice: Model X would be most effective. The wind channels would allow wind to flow through the seawall and reduce the amount of water that could flood the city.
